Jacob Wood A collection of whatsits, howsits, and whysits.
  • Inspirational
  • Projects
  • Learning

    I am adopting a philosophy of “learn the basics often” in an attempt to insure my practices coincide with best practices. Occasionally it is desirable to learn a task in a novel way and contrast the approach with the industry standard approach as a means of potentially evolving the standard approach but this philosophy should provide a chance to reflect and redirect when necessary.

    This a list of courses I have taken and look forward to adding to:

    Course Name Institution Instructor(s) Platform Date Link
    Into to Machine Learning Kaggle Dan Becker Kaggle January 2020 Link
    Python Kaggle Colin Morris Kaggle January 2020 Link
    Linux Journey LinuxJourney Open Source LinuxJourney January 2020 Link
    Computational Neuroscience University of Washington Rajesh P. N. Rao, Adrienne Fairhall Coursera January 2020 Link
    Simulink Onramp Mathworks Mathworks Matlab November 2019 Link
    Practical Deep Learning for Coders Fast.ai Jeremy Howard Fast.ai June 2019 Link
    Machine Learning Stanford Andrew Ng Coursera April 2019 Link
    Julia Scientific Programming University of Cape Town Juan H Klopper, Henri Laurie Coursera February 2019 Link
    Hypersonics – from Shock Waves to Scramjets University of Queensland David J. Mee et al edX December 2018 Link

    UCSD edX courses make up the Data Science MicroMasters. Note: audited courses do not receive access to homework questions or assessments on the edX platform, so these courses are far less thorough than you might hope.

    Mit OCW courses make up the Bachelor of Science in Computation and Cognition (Course 6-9) from MIT
    “The joint bachelor’s program in 6-9 is designed to give students access to foundational and advanced material in electrical engineering and computer science, as well as in the architecture, circuits, and physiology of the brain, and computational approaches to cognition and intelligence.”

    Bolded are available on OCW
    Italic are similar to previous UCLA coursework
